REPORT ON THE EVACUATION OF GOVERNMENT DEPARTMENTS. lt On the 6th September, 1939, the War Cabinet directed that preliminary action should be taken forthwith to facilitate the evacuation of Government Departments from London on the understanding that the final decision to order the move should "be taken by the War Cabinet later. 2. On the 8th September the Office of Works were authorised by the War Cabinet to requisition the office accommodation required and it was agreed that the supply staffs of the Admiralty and Air Ministry and also certain less essential staffs ( " B " staffs) scheduled to be evacuated under the "Yellow" move should be evacuated from London immediately. 3. On the 3rd October the Civil Defence Committee (C.D.C.-(39), 4th Conclusions, Minute 1) had before them a first report from the Sub-Committee on the Evacuation of Government Departments (the Douglas Sub-Committee) based on a re-survey of the office and living accommodation available. Considerable apprehension was expressed by Ministers as to the practicability of the general evacuation of Government Departoents from London and as to the inevitable loss of efficiency which must follow dispersal which, coupled with inadequate billeting accommodation for the staffs, might, it was felt, easily lead to a serious breakdown in the machinery of Government. 4. The Committee accordingly remitted to the Douglas Sub-Committee for re-examination the plans for the "Black" move (i.e. the move of the most essential Government staffs) to the Western counties with a view to determining whether a more workable plan could be devised.
